articles.title: Deafness reversed: Single injection brings hearing back within weeks
articles.content: A cutting-edge gene therapy has significantly restored hearing in children and adults with congenital deafness, showing dramatic results just one month after a single injection. Researchers used a virus to deliver a healthy copy of the OTOF gene into the inner ear, improving auditory function across all ten participants in the study. The therapy worked best in young children but still benefited adults, with one 7-year-old girl regaining almost full hearing. Even more exciting: this is just the start, as scientists now aim to target other genes that cause more common forms of deafness.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant medical breakthrough where gene therapy successfully restores hearing in deaf individuals, offering hope for many affected by congenital deafness. This advancement is inspiring and has the potential to improve quality of life dramatically.

articles.title: Parkinson’s reversal? One drug brings dying brain cells back to life
articles.content: Stanford researchers discovered that dialing down an overactive enzyme, LRRK2, can regrow lost cellular “antennae” in key brain cells, restoring vital dopamine communication and neuroprotective signals in a mouse model of genetic Parkinson’s. After three months on the LRRK2-blocking drug MLi-2, damaged circuits revived and early signs of neuronal recovery emerged, hinting that timely treatment could not only halt but reverse disease progression—and perhaps benefit other Parkinson’s forms.
articles.reasoning: This article reports a significant medical breakthrough where a drug has shown potential to reverse Parkinson's disease progression in a mouse model, offering hope for future treatments and recovery for patients.

articles.title: Sweet-smelling molecule halts therapy-resistant pancreatic cancer
articles.content: A compound best known for giving almonds and apricots their aroma may be the key to defeating hard-to-kill cancer cells. Japanese researchers found that benzaldehyde can stop the shape-shifting ability of aggressive cancer cells, which lets them dodge treatments and spread. By targeting a specific protein interaction essential for cancer survival—without harming normal cells—benzaldehyde and its derivatives could form the basis of powerful new therapies, especially when combined with existing radiation or targeted treatments.
articles.reasoning: This article reports a promising scientific breakthrough in cancer treatment, specifically targeting therapy-resistant pancreatic cancer cells with a compound that could improve survival and treatment outcomes without harming normal cells.

articles.title: Why anger cools after 50: Surprising findings from a new menopause study
articles.content: Anger isn’t just a fleeting emotion—it plays a deeper role in women’s mental and physical health during midlife. A groundbreaking study tracking over 500 women aged 35 to 55 reveals that anger traits like outbursts and hostility tend to diminish with age and menopause progression. This shift could signal enhanced emotional regulation during and after the reproductive transition. Surprisingly, the only form of anger that remained steady was suppressed anger.
articles.reasoning: The article presents scientific findings that suggest emotional regulation improves with age and menopause, which is a positive insight into women's mental health during midlife. This can provide hope and understanding for many women experiencing these changes.
